Almost forty years ago, a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747-230 B was shot down over the Sea of Japan by Soviet Air Defence Forces, in what would soon be referred to as the "KAL007 Incident", and is thought by many to be one of the most "tense and dangerous situations" of the Cold War. At that time, I was a first officer on a KC-135(R) serving with NATO forces, and in support of NATO's/OTAN's "Northern Defense Forces". Within twenty-four hours of the shootdown, my ship and its crew were "baking in the sun" on the beach of a friendly Pacific ally.

Eleven days later, three fellow crew members, and myself began experience symptoms of malaria, after we'd noticed that our sleeping quarters/barracks began having problems with the building's air conditioning system, and later learned that one of the "civilian locals", had opened a rooftop fresh air access system, in an effort to make everyone more comfortable until repairs could be completed. None of the brass was notified that this had been done, otherwise, we'd have "donned the netting" to stay safe....

To make matters worse, one of our 'team of four' managed to acquire gonorrhea that very same week. "One has not lived, until he or she has gotten malaria AND the CLAP - at the very same time."

So good to see your sister back home for a bit. The video of your visit to Africa when she was there in the Peace Corps remains one of my all-time favorite YouTube videos. I lived two years in Colombia, and it's a beautiful place with beautiful people and delicious food. Any of Colombia's social problems are avoidable, especially now that the FARC are throwing down their weapons and are being repatriated (there's a story behind what all that means, but it's too long for here). Having locals who can show you where to go and where not to go can be useful.

There are a few different species of malaria causing trypanosomes of which their virulence in humans is different. I lived in Sub Saharan Africa for two years MANY years ago now. I got malaria four times. I don't know which particular species of trypanosome I had because I never got tested. The prophylaxis drugs that we took was supposed to prevent the malarial parasite, which we WOULD get, from becoming full blown within us. Even if you didn't get the fever and chills and other symptoms, you still were infected with the parasite. Taking a heavy curative dose of drugs either orally or by injection would "cure" you and that is what I did. A few days of feeling very bad followed by a couple of days of being very weak... and you would be over it. Over the years, however, the trypanosomes have evolved and have become resistant to drugs that used to work well so we have found new ones. Which in turn will eventually become ineffective. Malaria is only going to be eradicated by a full on war against the parasite by various means. One of the best would be to genetically alter the vector (the mosquito) so that they are no longer suitable intermediate hosts for the parasite. Another way would be to release sterile males into the environment so that the population of mosquitoes could be reduced. This second method would, however, impact the local ecology because the mosquitoes themselves are part of an established food web. The problem with the whole malaria question in, however, that it is a problem in the developing world and not in developed countries so the money drive for profit to eradicate it is not there. We as a human society have to decide that we want everyone in the entire world to be healthy and not silo ourselves off via nationalistic rhetoric.

2:28 thick film showing plasmodium falciparum and plenty of it, mostly trophozoites, 1 gametocyte. The staining technique is better than most of my colleagues would normally have done in UK. It was perfectly made, but then we only do a couple a day, they probably do dozens over there. As a matter of fact, I had colleagues who'd come from Africa and they said generally people don't bother doing lab tests to check a diagnosis of malaria. If you have a fever, you take antimalarials in the first instance.

I don't see any malarial parasites in your thin film at 3:00, but its a small section of the slide and its out of focus. Different species of malaria look different under microscope and part of my job was to identify the species. Not all species enlarge the red cells, not all make the red cells look spotty. The main thing on both of these slides is ignoring the white cells which might be freaking out your viewers.

Interesting malaria fact:  Sickle cell is a human genetic response to malaria.  This makes sense because the infection rates of malaria occur mostly in Africa where mosquitos are most present, and the people who are stricken with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) are largely of African and in some cases Arabian descent.  Now why is Sickle cell a response to malaria?  It lies in the shape of the cell.  Red blood cells are normally round and squishy, almost jello like.  This is so red blood cells can squeeze through capillaries and alveoli.  Sickle cell is essential a hard red blood cell in a crescent moon shape, hence "sickle".  As stated by Mr. Sandlin, malaria uses the contents of red blood cells to reproduce and eventually burst the squishy cell.  Since SC is hard, malaria cannot burst the cell.  The downside to this is that SCs can block capillaries and alveoli, causing oxygen deprived parts of the body.  Thankfully, the lifespan of these cells is much much shorter than those of normal red blood cells to prevent this blockage problem so they are broken down by the body before damage can be done, but  SCD becomes a problem when a certain healthy red blood cell to SC ratio is reached.  I am not certain what this ratio is.

Hi Destin,
I'm not sure if you have concluded that these eggs you saw while fishing are mosquito eggs. I could offer you a different explaination: I'm studying biomedicine in Germany and just a few days ago I've learnt about many different parasites. One of them is called Shistosoma mansoni (or "blood fluke" is what google translater tells me). It is often found in standing freshwater and widespread in Africa. It's between host is a freshwater snail. If animals bath in this water, Shistosoma mansoni makes it's way directly through their skin. The symptoms of an infection are pretty similar to those of malaria, but often the infections show symptoms in a very late state of the sickness. BUT these eggs appeared to be pretty huge. I've never seen real Shistosoma egss, hence I dont know their size. Parasites usually reproduce themselves asexually in the between host and sexually in the final host, so i probably am wrong by assuming these are Shistosoma eggs. Though you might want to get checked for shistosoma if you develop certain symptoms.
Greetings!

Each ecological niche has its peculiarities, until recently my country was only controlling the disease, avoiding mechanisms of extermination mainly so that we did not interfere in nature, since the main focus was in the state of Amazonas. After several studies and conjectures, it was found that exterminating the mosquito, vector of the disease, would only reduce the diversity of the family by 1%, and that in this way there would be no significant damages in the environment in question. The main concern was that eliminating mosquitoes would eliminate pollinating agents in the same way, which in fact did not occur.
In 2015 we had fewer cases of malaria, there are several techniques that can be used for mosquito extermination and control: genetic transformation (as used in the United States to exterminate Cochliomiya hominivorax, an insect responsible for causing myiasis in cattle) , bacteria in the case of Australia, or the use of drugs that is the case of Brazil, following the WHO recommendations in the synergistic applications of artemeter and lumefantrine (AL), artesunate and amodiaquine (AS + AQ), artesunate and mefloquine (AS + MQ) and artesunate and sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (AS + SP) and application of insecticides.
